moves.1. d4 e6 2. Nf3 b6 3. e4 Bb7 4. Bd3 Bb4+: Bb4+ allows White to finish building a strong pawn structure in the center while gaining a tempo.  It's now up to Black to try to undermine White's center.
moves.5... Bd6: d6 is not a great square for the Bishop.  It reduces Black's ability to counter in the center with pawns.
moves.6. O-O c5 7. Bg5 f6: f6 is a little bit weakening.  Black could have taken the opportunity to develop the N.
moves.8. Bh4 Ne7 9. e5 fxe5 10. dxe5 Bc7 11. R: Moving the Q to g6 allows the e7 N to hang.  Although the e4 R is also loose, White strikes first.
moves.15. Bxe7 Rf7 16. Re3 Rxe7 17. Nb5 Na6: Black finishes development and hopes apparently to attack on the Kingside.  But the N is hanging.
moves.18. Qa4 Rf8 19. Qxa6 Bb8 20. Nd6: The N on d6 is a real annoyance for Black.  For one thing, it prevents doubling the Rs on the f file.
moves.20... Qc2 21. Qe2: White offers to exchange and head toward an endgame with a piece to the good.
moves.21... Qxe2 22. Rxe2 Bxd6 23. exd6: By exchanging, Black makes the material deficit loom larger.  Although Black has an open f file and two Rs, it's not clear that an attack could be successful now.
moves.23... Ref7 24. Rd1 h6: Thinking about a Kingside attack perhaps.  Rxf3 just loses the exchange.
moves.25. Ne5: Now White is also winning the d7 pawn, making a dangerous passed pawn.
Black is going to lose significant material trying to deal with the passed pawn.
With the R on the e file, Black's K can't get to the passed pawn.
moves.33. Re8+ Kg7 34. Nc6 d3 35. d8=Q: The pawn promotes in plenty of time to stop Black's d pawn.
moves.35... g4 36. Qxd3: Mate is going to follow in a few moves, after White plays Re5, Qd6, Re7, Qd8.  White can safely ignore the Black pawns.
